prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The primary observational goal is to detect high-velocity emission from gas orbiting the black hole. In NGC 1332 we find velocities up to +-500 km/s from the systemic velocity. The spectral window width of 2400 km/s is extremely important so that we can detect very high-velocity emission, should it be present. Our observations will enable us to examine the full velocity range of +-1200 km/s relative to the galaxy's systemic velocity, in 20 km/s channels, which will be ideal for detecting the highest velocity emission present in the galaxy nucleus and mapping the disk kinematics accurately.
We will use spectral averaging to 5 km/s to lower the data rate. This will allow us to recalibrate the data to channels narrower than 20 km/s if the S/N allows.
We add a second baseband adjacent to our primary baseband to obtain an additional continuum measurement. This may be useful in the event that a target has a compact radio core from a weak AGN. For this continuum baseband, high spectral resolution is not crucial and we request 40 km/s resolution to minimize the data rate.

We require that our observations should (a) resolve the expected BH sphere of influence, (b) retain sensitivity to angular scales equal to the disk radius, and (c) be obtainable in a single ALMA array configuration for optimal efficiency. All of these requirements can be met with a requested angular resolution of 0.3 arcsec.

The CO fluxes of our targets are unknown on the angular scales of interest for this program. We base our sensitivity requirements on the following considerations, using results from our Cycle 2 observations of similar targets as a guide.
1) We select a channel width of 20 km/s as this is sufficient to accurately map the overall kinematics of these disks and carry out dynamical modeling. In our Cycle 2 targets NGC 1332 and NGC 6861, the spatially integrated CO emission from the disks shows double-horned velocity profiles with full widths of ~1000 km/sec. In NGC 1332, the CO(2-1) emission line from the central region of the disk has a brightness of approximately 60-70 mJy/beam depending on the spatial location (for a 0.3" FWHM beam) in the central velocity channel, and a line width of FWHM = 200 km/s near the disk center. (The line widths vary strongly over the disk, ranging from FWHM~200 km/s near the disk center to ~20 km/s at the outer edge.)
2) Our goal is to obtain a significant detection of the CO emission even if our targets have a central CO surface brightness an order of magnitude fainter than that of NGC 1332. That is, we aim to obtain S/N=10 for the brightest velocity channel in the line profile for a flux as faint as 6 mJy/beam. This sets a sensitivity requirement of 0.6 mJy. If the CO surface brightness is comparable to what we detect in NGC 1332 and NGC 6861, this will enable highly accurate measurements of the line profiles at each pixel enabling us to carry out spatially resolved dynamical modeling. If the CO surface brightness is too faint for such measurements, we will still be able to measure the spatially integrated flux and line profile shape, which is sensitive to the total enclosed gravitating mass. In the "field setup" pane, we list an expected peak brightness of 6 mJy/beam to represent our requirement for a high S/N detection down to this surface brightness limit.
3) Calibrations and overheads will take roughly 26 minutes per target. Our requested sensitivity of 0.6 mJy results in on-source integration times of approximately 20 minutes per target, which is a reasonable minimum exposure time in order that our program not be strongly overhead-dominated (i.e., a sensitivity target greater than 0.6 mJy in this case would result in extremely short on-source exposure times and an overhead-dominated program, which would not be an optimal use of ALMA time). Conversely, much deeper observations would not be justified at this stage given that the CO fluxes from these targets are unknown on the scale of the black hole sphere of influence. We note that our Cycle 2 program also set a sensitivity requirement of 0.6 mJy, and this provided excellent depth for detection of the high-velocity emission in NGC 1332, accurate measurement of the line profile at each spatial pixel in the disk, and spatially resolved dynamical modeling.

The primary observational goal is to detect high-velocity emission from gas orbiting the black hole. In NGC 1332 we find velocities up to +-500 km/s from the systemic velocity. The spectral window width of 2400 km/s is extremely important so that we can detect very high-velocity emission, should it be present. Our observations will enable us to examine the full velocity range of +-1200 km/s relative to the galaxy's systemic velocity, in 20 km/s channels, which will be ideal for detecting the highest velocity emission present in the galaxy nucleus and mapping the disk kinematics accurately.
We will use spectral averaging to 5 km/s to lower the data rate. This will allow us to recalibrate the data to channels narrower than 20 km/s if the S/N allows.
We add a second baseband adjacent to our primary baseband to obtain an additional continuum measurement. This may be useful in the event that a target has a compact radio core from a weak AGN. For this continuum baseband, high spectral resolution is not crucial and we request 40 km/s resolution to minimize the data rate.

We require that our observations should (a) resolve the expected BH sphere of influence, (b) retain sensitivity to angular scales equal to the disk radius, and (c) be obtainable in a single ALMA array configuration for optimal efficiency. Given the large overall size of the disk in NGC 4697 and the small expected size of the BH sphere of influence, we very slightly relax requirement (a) in this case, opting for an angular resolution of 0.25 arcsec. This makes it possible to retain sensitivity to an angular scale of 3.4 arcsec (the full extent of the disk) while still satisfying the requirement that the observations can be obtained in a single array configuration.

The primary observational goal is to detect high-velocity emission from gas orbiting the black hole. In NGC 1332 we find velocities up to +-500 km/s from the systemic velocity. The spectral window width of 2400 km/s is extremely important so that we can detect very high-velocity emission, should it be present. Our observations will enable us to examine the full velocity range of +-1200 km/s relative to the galaxy's systemic velocity, in 20 km/s channels, which will be ideal for detecting the highest velocity emission present in the galaxy nucleus and mapping the disk kinematics accurately.
We will use spectral averaging to 5 km/s to lower the data rate. This will allow us to recalibrate the data to channels narrower than 20 km/s if the S/N allows.
We add a second baseband adjacent to our primary baseband to obtain an additional continuum measurement. This may be useful in the event that a target has a compact radio core from a weak AGN. For this continuum baseband, high spectral resolution is not crucial and we request 40 km/s resolution to minimize the data rate.

We require that our observations should (a) resolve the expected BH sphere of influence, (b) retain sensitivity to angular scales equal to the disk radius, and (c) be obtainable in a single ALMA array configuration for optimal efficiency. All of these requirements can be met with a requested angular resolution of 0.35 arcsec. In principle a lower resolution of 0.7 arcsec would still satisfy these requirements, but in this case, given the extremely large size of the BH sphere of influence, a resolution of 0.35 arcsec will provide excellent resolution of the sphere of influence and will potentially permit us to carry out very detailed dynamical modeling to derive the BH mass to a higher degree of accuracy than for the rest of our sample.

The CO fluxes of our targets are unknown on the angular scales of interest for this program. We base our sensitivity requirements on the following considerations, using results from our Cycle 2 observations of similar targets as a guide.
1) We select a channel width of 20 km/s as this is sufficient to accurately map the overall kinematics of these disks and carry out dynamical modeling. In our Cycle 2 targets NGC 1332 and NGC 6861, the spatially integrated CO emission from the disks shows double-horned velocity profiles with full widths of ~1000 km/sec. In NGC 1332, the CO(2-1) emission line from the central region of the disk has a brightness of approximately 60-70 mJy/beam depending on the spatial location (for a 0.3" FWHM beam) in the central velocity channel, and a line width of FWHM = 200 km/s near the disk center. (The line widths vary strongly over the disk, ranging from FWHM~200 km/s near the disk center to ~20 km/s at the outer edge.)
2) Our goal is to obtain a significant detection of the CO emission even if our targets have a central CO surface brightness an order of magnitude fainter than that of NGC 1332. That is, we aim to obtain S/N=10 for the brightest velocity channel in the line profile for a flux as faint as 6 mJy/beam. This sets a sensitivity requirement of 0.6 mJy. If the CO surface brightness is comparable to what we detect in NGC 1332 and NGC 6861, this will enable highly accurate measurements of the line profiles at each pixel enabling us to carry out spatially resolved dynamical modeling. If the CO surface brightness is too faint for such measurements, we will still be able to measure the spatially integrated flux and line profile shape, which is sensitive to the total enclosed gravitating mass. In the "field setup" pane, we list an expected peak brightness of 6 mJy/beam to represent our requirement for a high S/N detection down to this surface brightness limit.
3) Calibrations and overheads will take roughly 26 minutes per target. Our requested sensitivity of 0.6 mJy results in on-source integration times of approximately 20 minutes per target, which is a reasonable minimum exposure time in order that our program not be strongly overhead-dominated (i.e., a sensitivity target greater than 0.6 mJy in this case would result in extremely short on-source exposure times and an overhead-dominated program, which would not be an optimal use of ALMA time). Conversely, much deeper observations would not be justified at this stage given that the CO fluxes from these targets are unknown on the scale of the black hole sphere of influence. We note that our Cycle 2 program also set a sensitivity requirement of 0.6 mJy, and this provided excellent depth for detection of the high-velocity emission in NGC 1332, accurate measurement of the line profile at each spatial pixel in the disk, and spatially resolved dynamical modeling.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: ALMA will make it possible to measure masses of supermassive black holes in early-type galaxies via an entirely new method, by mapping the kinematics of rotating, circumnuclear molecular disks. HST images provide an optimal method for pre-selection of targets, because ~10% of early-type galaxies have circumnuclear dust disks on arcsecond scales which are associated with regular rotational kinematics. We propose to continue our program, begun in Cycle 2, of observing CO(2-1) emission with subarcsecond resolution from early-type galaxies hosting dust disks selected from an extensive search of the HST archives. Our efficient observations will resolve the gravitational sphere of influence of the black holes and reveal rapid rotation from molecular gas in the inner disks, and we will carry out dynamical modeling to derive constraints on the black hole masses. Once we have determined the CO fluxes and linewidths, in future ALMA cycles we will propose to carry out deeper and higher-resolution observations that will provide exquisitely accurate black hole masses.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals:
2013.1.00229.S, "Circumnuclear molecular disks in early-type galaxies as a probe of black hole masses", PI: Barth
2013.1.00828.S, "Circumnuclear disks and black hole masses in nearby radio galaxies", PI: Barth

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Physics & Astronomy, California at Irvine, Univ of
